body.name: The Keeper of the Laugh: A Completely Gripping WW2 Historical Fiction Novel
body.description: A beautiful story of love and redemption set in the aftermath of World War II – perfect for fans of The Longest Echo and The Tattooist of Auschwitz.Munich, 1945. Max Fischer cannot remember anything from his life before the concentration camp. Not his family, not his occupation, not even his own name. All he is left with is the sickening, maniacal laugh that echoes in his head. More than haunting his every waking moment, the laugh is Max’s only connection to his lost past. For a holocaust survivor, recalling the past comes with a heavy toll.Just months after the allied forces liberated the camp that interned him, Max is introduced to the beautiful and wealthy Alexandra Brecholdt. The former Berlin actress seems adamant on taking Max into her care, but there is something she is too ashamed, or too afraid to tell him. The secret of her fortune, her survival—and her son.As Max’s memories begin to unravel, it becomes clear that the laugh is the key to his lost past. Restless, Max takes it upon himself to uncover its origins as Alexandra vows to protect him from the horrible truths it hides. Their mutual hunger for life shows them the true meaning of courage, love, and hope – and the ultimate secret behind the laugh. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book held my attention from start to finish. It is one of those books that I wish it had not ended!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The simple, yet intricate antithesis that holds the foundation of this novel is what really did it for me. It is the constant reminder for both the central character and the reader, of a presumably horrific event from the past, which is only manifested through internal laughter. I think the strong contrast creates an eerie atmosphere at times, and evokes feelings of fear due to its unusual nature. Furthermore, the plot is solid, it unfolds very nicely, the characters have great interactions in multiple ways, and of course you’re always wondering what happens next.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This novel disturbed me, it also enlightened me. A reminder of evil which lurks in the hearts of some, deep pain in others, and of a history we must not forget. Excellent!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I had a hard time following this story, however I needed to finish it to understand the end. All I will say is, its a unique read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Revenge is BEST served cold
reviews.reviewText: Yes, as cold as the grave. Can any if you fault him for how he's felt for over a decade and lost an entire family? I can't. For his son to take that revenge is delicious. My ancestors were Jewish and fled from the pogram in Europe long before I was born. They changed their names at the time if marriage and somehow, in the confusion of the times got a way with it. Had the same happened to me as Max, I'd have wanted to do the very same to his torturer. Not to the child, they're innocent. But the bully boys and other assorted nazis, they deserve nothing but the same treatment meted out to our Jewish ancestors who did not escape the vile hitler.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautifully written story!
reviews.reviewText: This was an amazing and disturbing story of the mental struggles of a holocaust survivor. The author jumps among several time periods to create suspense. And nothing is settled until the very last sentence.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Makes you think
reviews.reviewText: An interesting story that really keeps you on your toes. This story really pulls the reader in, as you want to understand Max's past as badly as he does. It is also interesting how this book also depicts the effect that extreme trauma can have on memory and the backside of that coping mechanism. Interesting and hard to put down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars How the war affected generations in Europe
reviews.reviewText: Such a good read. The Keeper of the Laugh is about a concentration camp Survivor (Max) of extreme physical and psychological torture. When he gains freedom he is suffering from memory loss and is slowly brought back by a woman who had consorted with the Reich to survive the war.Max denies his son, fearful of a relationship. He recalls being forced to entertain the military leaders at Auschwitz by clowning, if he failed to make them laugh. a fellow prisoner, and Max's oldest son were killed.Max found comfort by continuing work as a clown after the war. A very successful circus was created. and thry traveled to South America. There, Max was able to track down the heartless Nazi who caused his pain in the camp and the man was arrested, to face prosecution. Max's son makes a decision that he hopes will free his father from the echoes of Nazi laughter in his head.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 12, 2023
reviews.reviewText: An amazing book such a wonderful story it had me unable to stop reading, brilliant l can’t wait to read another by this author

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: What a very hard to read book it was so sad those poor people who went through so much even after the war
